turn.text: Well, I'm relying on the opinion of Chief Justice Hughes who points out how he went through the legislative history and he has the citations there and, of course also, rely on my favorite author, among the Court of Appeals' judges, Judge Friendly and he found a case who also went into it.

They're convinced that regardless of what the state of labor relations and what have you is today, when this Act was passed, it was passed for this expressed purpose, and both committees, rather the committees of both houses made it clear that they were not beginning to be involved in any private interest points.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well General, if the proceeding only deals with public rights by this statute to say that any injured party could appeal.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It's because as the cases we have cited, it gives the private party the public -- private attorney-general point.
It's the only way it'll get to the Court of Appeals.
The Board's not going to take it up and the General Counsel is not going to take it up.
And I think and heard in the Act is for the Court of Appeals to have an opportunity to pass on the Board's actions.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well -- but the injured person would be pursuing a private right with me rather than the public right --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and would be controlling that situation?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir, but that's why the Court says that in that instance, he's not a private individual.
He's a private Attorney General.

The -- it's in the -- I think if I could quote from Judge Friendly's opinion in the Teamsters case, “The General Counsel cannot appeal from his own Board's decision, the respondent has no motive to do so, and this portion of the statute would thus be rendered nugatory unless the charging party was allowed to come in”.
And I think that's what these cases stand for.
The major one is the American Newspaper Publishers, but that's the reason for it but still it's -- it's in the public interest.
It's in the public's interest to find out whether or not the Board did find or did not find it.

But I don't think that helps in the other instance at all, because the case is in the Court of Appeals, and I don't see how we can assume that the General Counsel is not going to make as good a presentation as Mr. Rauh, at least he'll try to.
And the record -- as they're designating the record, in most of the cases, I run across, the whole record goes up anyhow.
But at some places, they do designate the record.
I think also on the question that he raise about going back to the Board, provided the case is sent back to the Board and that he will automatically have a right to come up, I'm not too sure he does.
But even if he does, he admits that the law of the case would have been settled before he gets there.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: May I ask Mr. Solicitor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Has there been any effort to get Congress to amend the Act along the lines of Section 8 of the Hobbs Act?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Not that I know of at that court.
The Board says, they do not know of it.
And this Amalgamated case has been on books since 40, since 1940.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I mean even after that Blue Ribbon panel said this ought to be done.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I would like to say that on that -- the only thing I could say about that is that Professor Cox who wrote the -- who made the original study when he became Solicitor General Cox, approved the position that the Government took in these particular cases.

And since I happen to know some of the names that were mentioned in regards to a question earlier, I can guarantee you without having to read all the proceedings that they were not all in agreement on any one point.
And I -- do you agree with it?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, General I'm still -- I'm still bothered by this problem if -- when the statute says that any injured party may appeal and that an injured party does appeal, does the Court of Appeals determine only public rights, or does it perceive to determine on the record, the private rights of the parties in the case?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The scheme of the statute is their public rights.

And the -- I think the best way we come to grips is that they're back pay cases where they find the management guilty of an unfair labor practice in order them to do this, this, this and to pay back pay in blank dollars to blank men.
That's still public, it's not private until that money actually gets to it because the Board has given authority once they issue that order.
They might still cut it down.
There's still negotiation.
There's still possibility of settlement.
And even when it gets to the Court of Appeals as a possibility of settlement in the public interest --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well then, Mr. Solicitor --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- not as to whether A, B, C gets a hundred bucks.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor, let's concede for the moment that there are public rights involved, and that the issue before the Court of Appeals is a matter of public right, does it necessarily follow that therefore intervention in the Court of Appeals should not be allowed by that court to aid in the consideration of whatever the public right might be, it doesn't have to be a private right to permit intervention in a manner -- I suppose there is a public right involved when a charging party, a charged party is successful, and he's permitted to intervene there although where I suppose we're dealing with the public right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, but he loses something.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, he may, but it's a -- but it doesn't become a private right just be in one case and a public right in another.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I don't know.

It seems to me that as to whether or not the Court Of Appeals should have the benefit of whatever the charging party has to offer, that can be covered to a certain extent by brief amicus which is usually granted, very seldom that the Courts of Appeals allow argument on which he just filed a brief amicus.
But you see, obviously, the petitioners in this case want more than to give to the Court of Appeals their position.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But they want what a -- what a successful respondent gets.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, they -- no sir, they want to argue in addition to what General Counsel is going to argue.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well that's true, that's true.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what could they have in addition to what General Counsel has?
General Counsel is representing the prosecution.
He must know as much as they know, he's tied to the record.
He can't go outside of the record.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, this is really getting down to it then, isn't it?
Isn't it a consideration of the -- isn't a judgment of whether, whether the charging party really would contribute much to these proceedings?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or whether he could --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that the question?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir, whether he could in his own personal interest --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do any more than the General Counsel would?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, take for example the petition for certiorari.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, if the Board loses, the Board, on the advice of the General Counsel decides whether or not they're going to apply for certiorari.
Once that decision is made, they then come to the Solicitor General to find out whether or not they're going to petition for certiorari.
But certainly this third party wouldn't be required to come to the Solicitor General.
And he held the public interest case would be in the hands of a private individual.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it was suggested that just because he became a party, he don't have all the rights of the party, that might be one of them that didn't have.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, it would be very difficult under the supervisory power of this Court could go into that very great detail.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And I think the -- well, to sum up, I think number one, this Court should make it quite it clear that there is no right to intervene as a party, and as to whether or not the Court wants to leave the Court of Appeals with some discretion.
I think that's up to the Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, don't you think, isn't it -- in 18 as your position that this ought to be a matter of discretion rather than a right about the -- about the -- you think the successful respondent ought to be allowed to intervene in the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well I'm worried about that case where -- well, to put it simply the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think that's a matter of right or a matter of discretion similar to -- I take it from your footnote --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- in your brief, that you think it's by analogy that 24 (b) in the District Court.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Right.
And I checked incidentally Mr. Justice -- when I checked on the new proposed rules --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The new appellate rules?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The new appellate rules, they follow the general rule which doesn't intend to give anybody any right to intervene, just a general language that's in most of the Courts of Appeals.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Does it deal with intervention?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Just that it is in the regular rules of the courts, the individual Courts of Appeals.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What does it say, just the intervention (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, the party may intervene by filing this, this, and this and leave them to the whole jurisdiction, I mean discretion to the Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So it is a discretionary matter?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.
The point that I'm worried about is the case where the Union asked for a 100%, and gets the 65%.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And there's a real good solid --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- issue there.
That's the one I'm worried about but I've also find, if I may say so that a lot of bad rules are made and looking forward to cases that might never come up.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I take it 18 then if the court have reversed this -- the Court of Appeals, we would do so in terms of an abuse of discretion.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think so, yes sir.
Because of the -- most of the cases have gone the other way.
Indeed they, this is the first time they've gone this far.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well the -- the point has been made and suggested -- if we take all of these other rights, to weigh the right, to block settlement, the right to petition etcetera is in fact back to the status of amicus curiae.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's -- except you have oral argument, it will make --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oral argument -- oral argument.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- anymore work for the lawyers, Mr. Solicitor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think that about -- did we got it here?

May it please the Court, I think on the basis of that, with the brief and with the one explanation, the appendix which has all of the different materials from the different agencies, I would like to advise the Court that that material was obtained from the agencies by letters from the Solicitor General and correspondents back and forth.
And we have in the files those letters providing anybody who would need them.

And the final point is that bear in mind, if you will, the first part of our appendix where we set out the number of cases involved from different agencies, when we try to lump NLRB with all the other governmental agencies, this problem is a pretty tough one, and I believe it is a right for the court to decide.

And number one, of course in 18 to reverse, and in the other one, 53 to affirm and make the rule crystal clear as to what it has already been in most of the Circuit, unless there are further questions.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Mr. General.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You referred to the (Inaudible) case which I have now just read.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did you gain the support for your side -- your arguments from that or the other side, which --?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I gain considerable support from the other side.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: From the other side?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.
But --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Very much like the Court went a long way there, isn't it, to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- allow the Union to intervene because it had an interest, although it had no original right to bring the case up.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And especially with one judge signed it, a single judge signed the order and I -- we went back to the briefs and all and I'm just in a loss as to it, but I -- I couldn't at least, I couldn't ignore it.
But I don't think it's in any way overrule Amalgamated at all.
I don't think it begins to overrule it and I don't think it touches the public interest point.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, Mr. Solicitor, I take it that there are cases.
I know you don't like to anticipate cases, but there are cases where the question about the unfair labor practice is identical with the breach of contract point.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And I suppose the Court of Appeals' decision on the unfair labor question would be rather relevant and only on the contract issue.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, they have had long gone --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And perhaps dispositive of the Union's claim or the individual's claim of the breach of contract?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, they've gone both ways on that.
The courts have -- I have seen them go both ways on that and I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what about this case?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well on --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Does this got -- is this a breach --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well this is, once it -- they have alleged in their action, as I understand it, that this is an unfair labor practice and the NLRB has taken jurisdiction of it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but what if it's a breach of contract, too?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, they picked the forum, the Union picked the forum.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know they picked the forum, and they also -- they want to stay in it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well I don't think once you picked the forum --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They want to stay in the court, they want to -- they want to get up from the Court of Appeals and participate there because the disposition of the question may dispose their contract claim.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, that -- they're arguing on that point just as bad as the other argument.
Once they picked the forum, they don't control the rules of the forum.
And once they become a party in the Board hearing, that does not carry through.
I mean they picked the forum, they came into the NLRB.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I mean where -- what's the their position going to be if they file 301 suit in the District Court for breach of contract, and the Court of Appeals and the Circuit has already decided the unfair labor practice case and the issue is identical.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think the Court of Appeals would say, that's the law of case, and that's it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then -- so that the Union's never had a hearing in the court.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh yes, the Union is -- was the Union -- the Union never asked for a hearing.
The Union asked --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They're asking for one in the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But they didn't start off with it.
They asked the General Counsel to represent them and prosecute this case, that's what they asked for, and that they got.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Are there any other question?
Thank you sir.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Mr. Rauh.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: May it please the Court.
We did not ask the General Counsel to prosecute this case for us.
We filed a charge when the Board rules made us a party if the charge resulted in a complaint.
Mr. -- the Solicitor General has stated that we are not a party in the general sense of the word, and I challenge that that we are not a party in the general sense of the word before the Board.

The ruling, the Board rules makes us a party, we call witnesses, we issue subpoenas for witnesses, we cross-examine, we affect the record, we go to the Board itself, how anybody can say we're not a full party before the Board?
The one thing we may not have is the right to block a settlement, we don't know about that yet.
The Court of Appeals is split and this Board and this Court has enacted.
But they suggest that we're not a party when we have the rights to do all the things the parties do before the Board.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Rauh, I think you know about that yet.
You know about that yet, so far as we -- a settlement in the Board or the Board case within the Board.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: No, it's split.
There's this division of a party --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Within the Board?

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: No, not at the Board, they think --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I say at the board level, do you know that you're -- that you can't do anything about bargains.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: That's right, but the Marine Engineers' case in the Third Circuit appears to indicate it's not valid now, but I'm not going to --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Even at the board level?

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: All these settlement cases are at the board level.
There's no settlement case involved that's gone to the Court of Appeals.
So, but to say we're not --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So you suppose I could anticipate what your position would be if we said you had the right to intervene?

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm not certain.
I would probably get to argue for this but I want to say this, that going to take the Amalgamated case where the Solicitor General had suggested that it's been criticized by the people.
-- I am not challenging the Amalgamated case.
I'm accepting the content part of it.
And as a matter of fact, the language of the case, which is more damaging to us than the result, that case was in ‘40.
In 1947, Congress really changed the basic structure when it passed Taft-Hartley.
It changed it from the Board's drive for unions to a management relations operation.

So there's a serious question whether the language of Chief Justice -- the result is settled as far as I'm -- there's a serious question whether all the language would be used today in view of the Taft-Hartley labor management relations a year -- seven years later.
But the one point I want to get over is before the Board, we're no second class citizen.
We are a first class citizen in every area including this one, in calling witness and cross-examining and appealing to the Board, we are a first-class citizen as a full party.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I know -- of course there's no question as I -- as I understand it.
You don't pretend to question the -- proposition that the charging.
If the General Counsel does not issue a complaint, that's the end of this.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There are no appeal at all.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- the charging party -- that's the end of the line.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely, absolutely.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, how much -- and I'm asking this for information, Mr. Rauh, I just need to know, how much actually control of the proceedings before the Board, does the General Counsel have or is designated?
And how much does the charging party have if -- after the complaint has been issued.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we call our own witnesses, we cross-examine their witnesses.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Thiers -- who's theirs?
You mean the other charging party (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, we cross-examine both the Board witnesses and the respondent's witnesses.

We're in this up to the hill, not you say that we'd let the General Counsel to put on his witnesses first, I suppose that's perfectly true that that would happen ordinarily, but we certainly have full status there -- or they're not -- we're carrying as much as of the ball, we can now, it's true, very often even small unions don't go into those cases and that the funds have -- it's right.
Their work is done at the expense of the Government --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And it's done (Voice Overlap) it's been my impression and as I have said this is informational, this isn't --

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: We have a full right to get subpoenas on --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But my impressions that the General Counsel ran a show in there, insofar as the proceedings --

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: I don't see that I would use the word 'ran the show'.
I think he may carry the major burden because the Union's -- if we made the charges nice, they have at government expense, they have the witnesses.
But if then, when we call our own witnesses and we cross-examine, and we go to the Board and we use different arguments, and that point about what could they have in addition to what the Board has?
We have arguments in addition.
I want to tell you about a case that had just came down in the Seventh Circuit, in Allis-Chalmers which is a companion case to Scofield.
There we had a question of whether it was proper to find workers' members for going through picket lines, to find this case through going through the picket lines, a very tough question.
We made a totally different argument from the Board in front of the Court of Appeals where we had been allowed to intervene by the consent of all parties.
And the court took our argument.
In other words, why is it strange if we should have different arguments than the Board?

Why is it strange when the Board wants us as a party because we know something about labor law, they should suddenly say, “When you get in front of the Court of Appeals we suddenly have got nothing to offer.”
We have something to offer and as far -- but what I want to make clear is on the certiorari point, Mr. Justice White.
I did not indicate that we had no rights in that respect.
Thus, a very --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I didn't -- I hope I didn't indicate what you indicated there.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: No, but I want to make clear that that is the difference.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's my indication.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, there is a difference and I want to come to the difference.
We obviously don't have a contempt right.
That's a public interest right.
It's quite likely we don't have a settlement, to block a settlement right.

But to get the legal problem settled, to get it before this Court, I would say we would have that right but I would say that most cases, this Court's going to deny a cert where a union seeks to bring an issue here, and the Board doesn't want it.
Now there are some cases where they grant a cert.Eagle-Picher is a case where you granted cert where we Union asked for it.
There's also Steel Worker's case in 376 U.S. where the Board didn't seek review, Steelworkers did, it was granted and reversed and so that there are cases where you would.
But ordinarily I would assume because I really think, I believe more in the public interest doctrine, than apparently Jaffe and Davis do in the things to which Thurgood Marshall referred.
It seems to me he was quite -- I accept that.
But it does seem to me, we would have a right to come here but not we would assume that the court would want the Government's views as the major matter.
Now Mr. --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Rauh, excuse me, did I correctly understand you to say, just now that where the Labor Board and the other party, let me say, agree on a settlement compromise that the Court of Appeals has the power to approve that settlement despite the opposition in your case, of your Union.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I have no question if they have the power to approve it, despite our opposition.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If there's a settlement, what involves the Court of Appeals in the approval of the settlement?

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Well they have always taken --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I understand --

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: -- all settlements have gone to the Court of Appeals.
Now the Solicitor General indicated that the judge, they generally approve them.
But they've always -- they've been taken there.
They rather indicate it's rather routine when he said on the bench but they always do --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean the proceeding is not --

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the proceeding --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- dismissed without prior approval of the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I don't know if the procedure is here but it may be that if we try to dismiss this case, we'd have to ask the Court's permission, and I think it's the same way.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well yes, but do you submit the terms of the settlement?

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the terms of the settlement that are approved by the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Consent decree?

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Consent decree (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what entered by the --

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I think that's correct.
It's a consent decree entered by the court.
May I just Mr. Justice Black, may I just --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.
turn.text: -- call your attention to number 18 blue, it's at page 40 of our brief, Footnote 32 deals with Section 10 (l) which was put in to the law in 47 which I believe is a very clear analogy in the statute to where private intervention is required even though --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Rauh I must say, if you suggest that that's what happens here, I've never known that to happen here, when the parties settle and they ask us to dismiss under the Rule 60, I've never looked at the terms of settlement, to decide whether the --

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Rauh, Jr.

turn.speaker: joseph_l_rauh_jr

turn.text: In conclusion, I like just to take up the Solicitor General on his definition of the difference between the two cases.
What we're really here before us, I say they're the same, he says they're different.
In an answer to a question, he said the difference is that the respondent loses something, so he's got a right to be in the Court of Appeals, but the charging party is different.
Now, I challenge that and I ask you to look once more in Fafnir.

If we have lost Fafnir and we have gone to the Court of Appeals, the respondent would have lost and had a right to intervene the Solicitor General, the Government says, would have had the right to intervene because they have lost the fact that time study people would come in to the plant.

Isn't here anachronism to say they couldn't go -- the company can go in there because time study people would come into their plant, but we can't intervene because we want time study people in their plant?
In other words, I'm saying that the difference between Scofield and Fafnir, illustrated by Fafnir if it were had gone the other way, makes clear that the cases are identical.
